power.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: the ability or right to control people or events
power.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: People should have more power over the decisions that affect their lives.
power.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: the position of having political control of a country or government
power.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: They seized power in a military coup.
De Gaulle came to power in 1958.
The voters have once again shown their support for the party in power.
power.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: the ability to influence people or give them strong feelings
power.translation[0].definitions[2].note: student/black/consumer etc power (=the political or social influence a particular group has)
power.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: the pulling power (=ability to attract people or attention) of major celebrities
power.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: the right or authority to do something
power.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The police have been given special powers to help them in the fight against terrorism.
The chairman has the power of veto on all decisions.
The committee has the power to order an enquiry.
power.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a natural or special ability to do something
power.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: After the accident she lost the power of speech (=ability to speak).
power.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: energy that can be used to make a machine work or to make electricity
power.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: the search for renewable sources of power
Many people are opposed to the use of nuclear power.
The ship was able to leave port under its own power (=without help from another machine, ship etc).
power.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: the physical strength or effect of something
power.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: the power of a cheetah’s long legs
The power of the explosion smashed windows across the street.
power.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: electricity that is used in houses, factories etc
power.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: Make sure the power is switched off first.
Parts of the country have had power cuts because of the storms.
power.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: a country that is strong and important and can influence events, or that has a lot of military strength
power.translation[0].definitions[8].note: world power (=a country that can influence events in different parts of the world)
power.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: Egypt is still a major power in the Middle East.
power.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: if a number is increased to the power of three, four, five etc, it is multiplied by itself three, four, five etc times
power.translation[0].definitions[10].def: the ability of a lens, for example in a pair of glasses or a microscope, to make things look bigger
power.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: the ability or right to control people or events
power.translation[0].note_box[0].section: People who have power never seem to use it to help others.
Women were trying to gain power in a male-dominated world.
The party will use all its power and influence to raise the issue in the Senate.
Questions have been asked about the way the police exercised their power.
The Church still wields enormous power in the country.
The central banks have huge power.
Parents had absolute power over children in those days.
Certain wealthy men exercised unbridled power.
The real power lay with the president’s advisers.
The country is locked in a power struggle between forces favouring and opposing change.
There has been a shift in the balance of power between the two countries.
Many of them were using their positions of power for personal advantage.
This cover-up is a scandalous abuse of power.
power.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 2: the position of having political control of a country or government
power.translation[0].note_box[1].section: be in power
The law was passed when the Democrats were in power.
come to power
Tony Blair came to power in 1997.
take power
Many people fled after the military took power last September.
seize power
His son seized power in a military coup.
assume power
He assumed power after the assassination of the former president.
win power
The prime minister is facing his toughest challenge since winning power.
rise to power
The Roman emperor Vespasian rose to power through command of an army.
return/be returned to power
The party was returned to power with a reduced majority.
hold power
Economic disaster befell the country during the decade when he held power.
restore somebody to power
In 2004, the army restored him to power.
sweep to power
Reagan swept to power by promising reforms.
cling to power
Mao Tse-tung, the leader of the 1949 Communist revolution, clung to power for 27 years.
somebody’s rise to power
The programme examines Saddam Hussein’s rise to power.
somebody’s return to power
Churchill’s return to power had an immediate effect upon Anglo-American relations.
power.translation[0].note_box[2].heading: – Meaning 5: a natural or special ability to do something
power.translation[0].note_box[2].section: mental powers
Is it possible to enhance your mental powers?
creative powers
A music teacher should have a real interest in developing children’s creative powers.
healing powers
The water was supposed to have healing powers.
magical/special/miraculous powers
Diamonds were once thought to have magical powers.
the power of speech
I was so surprised that I momentarily lost the power of speech.
the power of flight
Some birds have lost the power of flight over millions of years.
powers of observation
Experience improves our powers of observation, since it teaches us what to look for.
powers of concentration
As you get older, your powers of concentration may decrease.
powers of persuasion
She used all her powers of persuasion to convince Tilly that the move was a good idea.
be at the height of your powers
Fonteyn was still at the height of her powers as a dancer.
lose a power
He was a brilliant speaker, who never lost the power to influence people.
somebody’s powers are failing/waning
Mark felt that his creative powers were waning.
power.translation[0].note_box[3].heading: – Meaning 6: energy that can be used to make a machine work or to make electricity
power.translation[0].note_box[3].section: The accident raised doubts about the safety of nuclear power.
They use solar power for all their heating.
Is wind power the answer to the energy crisis?
Wave power can be used to generate electricity.
The factory is run on hydroelectric power.
Early engines were driven by steam power.
One problem is their reliance on coal as the main source of power.
power.translation[0].note_box[4].heading: – Meaning 11: a country that is strong and important and can influence events, or that has a lot of military strength
power.translation[0].note_box[4].section: Britain wanted to maintain her status as a great power.
There will be representatives from all the world's major powers at the conference.
The United States had replaced Great Britain as the dominant world power.
Russia had become a naval power equal to Spain.
He was charged with spying for a foreign power.
power.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to supply power to a vehicle or machine
power.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: It’s powered by a Ferrari V12 engine.
power.translation[1].definitions[0].note: Power is usually passive in this meaning
power.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to move with a lot of force and speed
power.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: His strong body powered through the water.
power.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: the ability or right to control people, organizations, events etc
power.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: I’m against giving too much power to one man.
He plans to resign after losing a power struggle within the firm.
power.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: the right or authority to do something
power.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The lawmakers approved the President’s demands for special powers to implement change.
He had almost unlimited executive powers to restructure the organization as he saw fit.
The Board of Trade invoked emergency powers (=special powers used to deal with an unusual dangerous situation) to stop an attempt to limit the soybean market.
power.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: a country or organization that is strong and has a lot of influence
power.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: The US is still the world’s leading economic power.
a war between film producers and some of cable TV’s biggest powers
power.translation[3].definitions[3].defi: an ability to do something, influence a situation etc
power.translation[3].definitions[3].exam: the job-generating power of small firms
power.translation[3].definitions[4].defi: energy that is used to make electricity, electricity itself, and the industries that produce it
power.translation[3].definitions[4].exam: Turn the power on with the switch.
doubts about the safety of nuclear power
renewable energy, such as wind and solar power (=power from the sun’s energy)
power.translation[3].definitions[5].defi: the ability of a machine to perform work
power.translation[3].definitions[5].exam: Supercomputers use multiple processors to vastly increase computing power and speed.
power.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: to supply power to a vehicle or machine
power.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: The car will be powered by electricity.
power.translation[4].definitions[1].defi: working by means of gas, NUCLEAR ENERGY etc
power.translation[5].definitions[1].defi: showing that you are an important person in a business organization
power.translation[5].definitions[1].exam: If you think you can have a power career and a fulfilling family life, you’re crazy.
the director’s power lunches with movie moguls in trendy restaurants
a power nap (=a short sleep during the day that allows you to work more effectively later)
